fields.description:
com.atlassian.crowd.embedded.api.PasswordCredential is not serializable, but it is a required property for any com.atlassian.crowd.model.application.Application implemention. Implementations of Application like CrowdEmbeddedApplication either need to make their PasswordCredential field transient (and reinitialize it during readObject or lazily on demand) or PasswordCredential itself needs to be marked as Serializable.

Should we be serializing credentials at all? Maybe we shouldn't even keep it in memory?

Found while investigating confluence FindBugs results. See also CONFDEV-1810
fields.summary: Fix serialization issue with CrowdEmbeddedApplication

There has been a lot of movement of the APIs but a lack of notes, updates, etc on the javadoc front.

We need to go through all the interfaces, exceptions, and major data objects in modules defined in the subtasks and make sure that javadoc is present on the class-level, method-level and on the return types/exceptions.

If a particular method is ambiguous, seek clarification with the team first.

fields.description:
The Crowd component poms are not specific enough about their SCM structure, and this is hurting us when building source distributions. See http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-changelog-plugin/faq.html#Why_do_the_child_modules_of_my_multi_module_project_have_wrong_SCM_URLs for details.

Right now, we simply exclude all the crowd artifacts from the confluence source distribution, because attempting to include them triggers this error. Fixing this will allow us to include crowd sources in the confluence source release (should we ever want to do that).
fields.summary: Crowd component poms inherit wrong scm info, preventing source distributions

fields.description:
The [Self-Service|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Granting+Crowd+User+Rights+to+a+User#GrantingCrowdUserRightstoaUser-AuthorisingNonAdministratorstoUsetheCrowdSelfServiceConsole] configurations demand admins to:

1. Add an extra directory to the *crowd* application;
2. Set this directory *Allow All to Authenticate* to *true*.

This will make Crowd start counting all the users from that directory against the license.

Access to the Self-Service console should be provided without counting extra users in the license.

*Workaround 1:* [Restrict|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Restricting+LDAP+Scope+for+User+and+Group+Search] the number of users that are visible to the LDAP Directory. This can be done using the groups that are already used by the other applications (["can login groups"|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Specifying+which+Groups+can+access+an+Application]). It is important to ensure that the groups will not be added to the Application -> Crowd Console -> Groups tab. This would give Admin permission to all the Users in the groups.

*Workaround 2:* If the Users can't be restricted in the directory, disable the Self-Service console in Crowd and allow users to change details in the Applications. To allow this to happen, ensure that the Apps *External User Management* setting is set to OFF. This will make the Apps display all the UI options for the users personal profile management (Change FullName, Email and Password). It's important to emphasize that the External User Management options in the Apps impact the UI options only. The Crowd integration functionalities will still be the same. 

* JIRA: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Configuring+JIRA+Options#ConfiguringJIRAOptions-Options

* Confluence: Administration Console > General Configuration > External User Management
fields.summary: Self-Service Console configurations counts extra users against the license

fields.description:
It might be possible to improve the performance of nested groups on Active Directory by using the tokenGroups attribute. This is a computed attribute that lists all the nested members of a group by their SID ("objectSid" attribute).

This was originally suggested in [a forum post|http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=21305&tstart=0] for Confluence, then developed as a popular custom Atlassian-User implementation by Swisscomm on CONF-17150.

h4. Workaround

You can take advantage of how Crowd uses the configuration, and force AD to do this anyway. This will mean your groups are all flattened in Crowd, but you will receive the same performance benefit. To do this, configure the following in the directory in Crowd:

# On the "Connector" tab:
#* Uncheck "Use Nested Groups"
#* Uncheck "Use memberOf for group memberships"
#* Check "Use the User Membership Attribute"
# On the "Configuration" tab:
#* Change the "User Group Attribute" to "memberOf:1.2.840.113556.1.4.1941:"
# Perform a full sync in Crowd
 #* If you had the directory configured to perform incremental synchronization, you will need to change it to full synchronization so that Crowd captures changes on nested groups.
fields.summary: Use tokenGroups attribute for nested group retrievals on AD

fields.description: When running through the setup of Crowd, I rushed through the Internal Directory step of the process. Wanting to review the options on that page, I pressed the back button in my browser, taking me back to the page for that step. After amending values, I pressed continue again. I received an error message telling me that I 'have already completed or are not up to this step.' Following that is a link to go to the correct setup step, but the markup for the hyperlink is escaped: "You have already completed or are not up to this step. Please click here to go to the correct setup step."
fields.summary: Hyperlink in crowd installation error message escaped unnecessarily

fields.description: The DebugLoggingPropertySet is not currently serializable. This causes problems if it needs to be cached into a database.
fields.summary: Make the DebugLoggingPropertySet serializable

fields.description:
Probably easy enough to have web sudo blanketing the entire web console.

The lack of this can be mitigated by using best practices: having a separate admin account from the regular day to day user account.
fields.summary: Implement Web Sudo for administrators accessing the Crowd web console
Users should have to re-authenticate before changing email address in the user console.

fields.description:
Crowd 2.1 will contain Start and Stop scripts.

Crowd could also include options to display the applications *status* (running/stopped/hanging/etc) and create Thread Dumps.

*Workarounds*
*Status:* run *{{ps -ef}}* to get the {{PID}} and then run *{{top -p PID}}* and check the process status.
*Thread dump:* run *{{kill -3 PID}}* to obtain a thread dump in Crowd's log file
fields.summary: Allow Crowd Scripts to provide Status and Thread Dumps

fields.description:
If I search only for active or inactive users all users with this status are returned regardless of the search terms I enter.
Only searching for active and inactive users (Active: All) respects the search terms.
fields.summary: Search terms only used when active field set to all.

fields.description:
In Crowd's Java client libraries:
{{HttpAuthenticator#setPrincipalToken}} adds a session attribute with the client's "Session Last Validation" as the key, and the current time as the value.
The client's "Session Last Validation" could potentially be null and trip up different applications in the chain (such as Apache Wicket).
Our application uses the client libraries and implements both normal authentication and SSO capabilities, and we discovered the error in the following scenario:

# Login to an application with a Crowd user that sets the token cookie.
# Browse to our application (clean of any former session info); the authentication filter picks up on the cookie and validates it via {{HttpAuthenticator#authenticateWithoutValidatingPassword}}.
# {{HttpAuthenticator#setPrincipalToken}} is invoked and adds a session attribute with a key of null (since the client has no former session last validation info) and the value of the current date.
# Filter chain progresses and eventually reaches Apache Wicket's filter which scans for it's own attributes within the session and gets hit by a null pointer exception.
fields.summary: HttpAuthenticator#setPrincipalToken adds session attribute with a null key

fields.description:
Currently the [page|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWDDEV/Password+Encoders] does not explain what are the conventions for the names and keys.

For instance:
{code}
key="mycompany.crowd.passwordencoders"
{code}
The convention is *<name_1>.<name_2>.passwordencoders*

If the last 's' is not added to "passwordencoders", the package will fail.

Would be good to have all the XML attributes clarified.
fields.summary: Improve Doc page for Password Encoders so that if can make explicit the naming conventions

fields.description:
Currently, Crowd will re-calculate the license every 2 hours (scheduled) or if the _recalculate link_ is clicked. 

If the admin enters a license that has a limit lower than the current number of users, Crowd will not let the admin know (error message or email), until the next scheduled count is run.

A license update should trigger a recalculation to inform the Admin if it is valid or nor (its limit is higher or the same as the current number of users).
fields.summary: Immediatelly show if the license count limit is still valid when updating the license
Wrong UI text on admin "reset password" screen

fields.description:
Form validation says "The supplied email address is invalid." on page http://localhost:8095/crowd/console/secure/user/add, if email address contains capital letters. For example:

"HELP@example.com" in the email field, fails with the error above.
"help@example.com" however, works without error. 

Since both deliver to the same email address, the lowercase equivalent is the workaround for this bug. 
However, it can confuse users who may think that something is wrong in the mail configuration of crowd, rather than the form.

An email address may contain upper-case letters as defined in RFC5322 (http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5322#section-3.4.1). 
including:

Uppercase and lowercase English letters (a-z, A-Z)
Digits 0 to 9
Characters ! # $ % & ' * + - / = ? ^ _ ` { | } ~
Character .
fields.summary: Email addresses with capital letters are incorrectly rejected

fields.description: Crowd token reuse is based only on IP address, not user agent.  This can mean that two different user agents can interfere with each others sessions on the same machine, or behind the same firewall on different machines.  A specific instance of the problem is with the Bamboo eclipse connector, this doesn't check to see if the user is already logged in before sending a username and password.  This causes the existing cookie to be invalidated on the server side, which because its the same token as used by a browser on the same host, causes the browser to be logged out.  Token reuse, if necessary, should at least take into account the user agent.
fields.summary: Crowd token reuse causes issues

fields.description:
The Contact objects have the exact same name as the normal User Objects, however it does not contain the same attributes.

Problems can happen if Crowd fetches the Contact instead of the User objects.

fields.description:
Logging in flat files is great for standard configurations.

However, when deploying Crowd in large organizations, it's annoying to have a lot of log files to monitor, rotate and backup. Especially when you already have some standard log management processes.

We centralize all logs using the syslog protocol. But in order to send Crowd logs to a syslog server, you currently have to modify a lot of files.
And I let Crowd developpers imagine the mess admins have to deal with when upgrading Crowd... Especially when the logging configuration is updated between releases. 

So, when will the admins get a convenient logging feature?
fields.summary: Easier syslog integration
Ensure that the crowd-administrators group and its members cannot be deleted from applications' Admin Consoles

fields.description:
User records include given names and family name fields.
Names are displayed as "$GivenName $FamilyName".

This is a hot-button problem for representing names in (at least) Japan, China & territories, and Vietnam.

For those users, they /expect/ to see their names written starting with their family name followed by their given names, and are uncomfortable to see it written differently.

We wish for:
  Japanese names to be displayed as "$FamilyName $GivenName ($KanjiRepresentation)".
  Chinese names to be displayed as "$FamilyName $GivenName ($HanjiRepresentation)".
  Vietnamese names to be displayed as "$FamilyName $GivenName".

Displaying user names to everyone's satisfaction has become a headache for many as we have to reverse family name and given names field values basically by hand.
At the very least, providing a toggle would be a great benefit to all of us, users and administrators alike. When toggled for a given user, their username would be displayed in the opposite order: "$FamilyName $GivenName". Provided this, we would compact the given name and Chinese character representation into the $GivenName field.
fields.summary: Display name ordering

Note that this applies to more-or-less all such "pop-up" boxes within the Crowd administration UI.

fields.description:
Forward slashes, "/", cause a variety of failures when included in DNs and User and Group Names.

Specific cases are:
* Adding a User or adding a Group fails when the user or group contains a "/".  The failure occurs before the actual create when the system is checking to see if the user already exists.  If the user or group already exists in LDAP with a name containing a slash then all other operations, e.g. authenticate & search, seem to work OK.
* When a search is performed against a DN that contains a "/" it fails with an error such as :
{code}
javax.naming.NameNotFoundException: [LDAP: error code 32 - No Such Object]; remaining name 'ou=kelpie/berrima,dc=example,dc=com'
{code}
This can be worked around by manually escaping the slash in the DN attribute e.g. ou=kelpie\2Fberrima,dc=example,dc=com

All these tests were run against OpenLDAP.
fields.summary: Forward slashes not escaped correctly in DNs etc.

Original issue title: Concurrent Modification Exception when iterating the list of username returned by UserManager in the client

There is a user poller in Studio's Google Apps integration that creates new users when new users have been found from Google.

If another class is iterating the list of usernames returned by Crowd's UserManager at the same time, a ConcurrentModificationException is thrown.

fields.description:
If a Delegated Directory is the first in the App Dir list, authentication is successful, but memberships are not amalgamated.

The authentication inside Crowd is successful, and the user is added to the Directory, however since the applications will not see the group amalgamation, they don't allow the users to login.

The problem is fixed if the Delegated Directory is set to *Allow All to Authenticate*.

*Workaround:* Set the Delegated Dir *Allow All to Authenticate* to true or add the necessary groups to the Delegated directory.

fields.description:
(Set as Critical because it can bring the instance down (if the count is higher than the current allowed value) and block any updates to the license)

Going to Crowd Administration -> Licensing and updating the license may cause Crowd to report the following exception:

{noformat}
com.atlassian.crowd.exception.PasswordEncoderNotFoundException: The PasswordEncoder 'atlassian-sha1' was not found in the Internal Encoders list by the PasswordEncoderFactory
at com.atlassian.crowd.password.factory.PasswordEncoderFactoryImpl.getInternalEncoder(PasswordEncoderFactoryImpl.java:35)
at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.directory.internal.InternalDirectory.authenticate(InternalDirectory.java:357)
at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.directory.internal.InternalDirectory.processAuthentication(InternalDirectory.java:198)
at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.directory.internal.InternalDirectory.authenticate(InternalDirectory.java:170)
at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.application.ApplicationServiceGeneric.authenticateUser(ApplicationServiceGeneric.java:215)
at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.application.ApplicationServiceGeneric.authenticateUser(ApplicationServiceGeneric.java:150)
at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.application.ApplicationServiceGeneric.authenticateUser(ApplicationServiceGeneric.java:233)
at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:597)
at org.springframework.aop.support.AopUtils.invokeJoinpointUsingReflection(AopUtils.java:310)
at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.invokeJoinpoint(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:182)
at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:149)
at com.atlassian.spring.interceptors.SpringProfilingInterceptor.invoke(SpringProfilingInterceptor.java:20)
at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:171)
at org.springframework.transaction.interceptor.TransactionInterceptor.invoke(TransactionInterceptor.java:106)
at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:171)
at org.springframework.aop.framework.JdkDynamicAopProxy.invoke(JdkDynamicAopProxy.java:204)
at $Proxy16.authenticateUser(Unknown Source)
at com.atlassian.crowd.console.action.License.doValidation(License.java:110)
at com.atlassian.crowd.console.action.License.doUpdate(License.java:50)
at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:597)
{noformat}


*How to reproduce:*
1. Update your Crowd instance to use a small license (ie. 10 user max limit) going to Admin -> Licensing.
2. Add more than 10 users to the the directory and ensure that they have permission to authenticate with Crowd.
3. Logout
4. Crowd will display a screen requesting for a license that supports more than 10 users.
5. Even if you provide a correct user name, password and license code, the exception will be displayed once you click _update_.

*Steps that have helped customers to recover access to Crowd:*

*1.* Backup the current <Crowd-Home-Directory>/crowd.cfg.xml file and then open it and change the license value at the <property name="license"> tag to a *Unlimited Evaluation license* obtained at http://my.atlassian.com *OR* to the new license that you are trying to apply to Crowd. Restart Crowd.

*2.* Change the {{current.license.resource.total}} entry value in the Crowd DB (table {{CWD_PROPERTY}}) to zero if it is different than zero and then restart Crowd.

*3.* Move <atlassian-crowd-2.0.4>/crowd-webapp/WEB-INF/lib/crowd-password-encoders-2.0.4.jar to the desktop and then run Crowd. Move the JAR back to the Crowd installation and then try to update the license again.
fields.summary: License Updates are causing Crowd to loose contact with the PasswordEncoder jar

fields.description:
When calling findPrincipalByName, if name *JSmith* is provided as an argument, *JSmith* (with this exact character case) will be returned. Does not matter if the name stored in the repository is *jsmith*. The name used as an argument is returned as the SOAPPrincipal name.

This impacts Applications that are not case-insensitive (like JIRA and Confluence). Other APIs will return the case stored in the repository, however findPrincipalByName will return the case used as an argument. A login attempt with a char case different from the one being used in the repository will provide to the Apps _wrong data_, possibly causing permissions loss.

The problem happens only if the [Lower Case Output|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Configuring+Options+for+an+Application] is disabled.
fields.summary: findPrincipalByName returns the Char Case used in the API argument, not the one returned as the API search result

fields.description:
Steps to replicate:

1) Map an application (Confluence in this case) to have delegated and direct authentication (Apache Directory Server, in this case)
2) Restrict the authentication to a few groups for direct authentication.
3) All all users to authenticate for delegated directory setup.
4) Place direct authentication directory as the first and the delegated authentication as the second in the "Order" column.
5) Log into the application (Confluence) with a user that does not yet exist internally in crowd and notice the "Incorrect username/password" error.
6) Reverse the directory order to have the delegated authentication as the first instead and log in again. This time the user can successfully log into the application (Confluence).

Tested this on Crowd 2.0.4 and Confluence 3.2.1_01. User reported the problem on crowd 2.0.6 and Crucible using Active Directory.
fields.summary: Mandatory to have a delegated directory first in the directory order to "auto" create a non-existing user

fields.description:
The UsnChangedCacheRefresher uses internal state to store information about previous synchronisations that will not work within a clustered environment.

* highestCommittedUSN - set on previous sync to track how far back to ask for changes
* guidUserMap - retrieved on first full sync used to map users to their guid's
* guidGroupMap - retrieved on the first full sync used to map groups to their guid's

When asking for deletes you only receive the guid which needs to be mapped back to the user record.
fields.summary: UsnChangedCacheRefresher uses internal state to track synchronisations

fields.description:
Currently, roles in Crowd are just another container for users - just like groups.

In fact, in Crowd 2.0, roles were migrated to be implemented as groups, with a "LEGACY_ROLE" group type.

We should officially deprecate roles as they do not offer anything more than groups do, and contribute to confusion both within the code and to end users.

This will mean deprecating:
- role queries on the SOAP API
- the "LEGACY_ROLE" group type
- deprecating roles in the UI or putting some notice in the UI to state that roles should not be used, use groups instead
fields.summary: Deprecate the current concept of Roles in Crowd

fields.description:
This improvement request is based on [this bug|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-1655], which makes the test search fail via the "Configuration" tab.
The above options like the "Active Directory Connector" configuration, helps in resolving the problem for "Delegated" configuration too by using the following workaround, as suggested by a customer:
{quote}
I found a workaround, by tweaking the database (cwd_directory_attribute) table.
I set: 
ldap.pagedresults to 'true' (was 'false'
I added 'ldap.pagedresults.size' with value '999'.

This makes the directory attribute similar for 'AD' and 'Deletaged AD'.
{quote}
fields.summary: Add "Use Paged Results" and "Paged Results Size" configuration options for "Delegated Active Directory" setup

fields.description:
The group membership lists for some users is sometimes losing some groups when some of the groups are nested. For example, a user customertest2 is a member of the group customer-test, which is a member of the group customer. Once the issue happens, the groups will show up as:
{code}
customertest2 (String) [jira-users, customer-test] (ArrayList)
{code}
but they should be:
{code}
customertest2 (String) [jira-users, customer-test, sdk-customer, customer] (ArrayList)
{code}

+Diagnostic steps:+ Check to see if flushing the cache on the client (e.g. Confluence Admin Console -> Cache Statistics -> Flush All) fixes the problem temporarily. 

This membership error is cached in the com.atlassian.crowd.integration-all-memberships cache.

*Workarounds:*
We have still not been able to find the source of the problem within the confluence code, however we do know that someone the confluence caches are affecting the crowd caches. 

We have attached the [crowd-integration-client-2.0.7-CWD-1996.jar|http://jira.atlassian.com/secure/attachment/40829/crowd-integration-client-2.0.7-CWD-1996.jar] which shades net.sf.ehcache to com.atlassian.crowd.shaded.ehcache. What this means is that there is no possible way that Confluence could have any effect whatsoever with the Crowd integration client's caches. They are essentially different classes that Confluence knows nothing about.

To apply the patch, upgrade to crowd 2.0.7 and in your confluence instance, remove the any other Crowd integration client JARs from
{{CONFLUENCE_INSTALL}}/confluence/WEB-INF/lib
and place the attached [crowd-integration-client-2.0.7-CWD-1996.jar|http://jira.atlassian.com/secure/attachment/40829/crowd-integration-client-2.0.7-CWD-1996.jar] and restart confluence.

Some Administrators try to use the http://my.atlassian.com login and password in Crowd's upgrade license UI (page displayed when the license limit was exceeded). Since the correct credential to provide is the Crowd Admin credential, the Upgrade fails.
